title: Michigan History as Told Through Archaeology
description: People have been living in Michigan for 14,000 years. Since the retreat of the glaciers, people have inhabited Michigan's rich landscapes and used its may resources. Here, you will find a brief, annotated, timeline of what we know about the history of Michigan from archaeology.

events.title: Tuscola County Mastodon
events.description: This mastodon, found in Tuscola County, is one of the most complete found to date. More than 75 complete bones, or 60-70% of the animal's skeletal mass, has been recovered. It probably lived between 13,000 and 11,000 years ago.  According to Dr. Dan Fisher, there is a good chance that people were involved with this site.  If so, this site will add to the growing body of evidence for interaction between humans and mammoths and mastodons.

events.title: Hacklander
events.description:
The Hacklander site consists of a small Archaic component (radiocarbon dated to 4860-4680 BP), Middle Woodland component, along with a larger Late Woodland component. Radiocarbon dates from this later component place the site at AD 1020 +/- 110 and AD 1070 +/-100. This site is unique in that it had not been disturbed by historic farming prior to being excavated, and can tell us much more about the people who lived here.

Image courtesy of the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office.

events.title: Holtz
events.description:
This Native American camp was occupied for a single time period during the Middle Woodland. Excavations at the site in the 1960s located almost 2000 pottery sherds in at least two concentrations, representing 11 vessels. A hearth was also present. A variety of lithic artifacts were also found, along with evidence for elk and clams.

Image from Lovis (1971):54.

events.title: Bay Furnace
events.description:
The Bay Furnace was run by the Bay Furnace Iron Company who smelted iron here. It was constructed in 1869 and destroyed by fire in 1877. The town of Onota grew up around the furnace, and became the county seat of Schoolcraft County. Archaeological survey of the property has identified nine structures, three charcoal kilns, a lime kiln, and two furnaces.

Image from www.fs.usda.gov/.

events.title: Schoolcraft Furnace
events.description: The Schoolcraft Furnace complex begain in 1868, processing ore from the Marquette Range.  It operated until 1877 when it was abandoned. Archaeological features include the furnace, a complex of charcoal kilns, two charcoal pits, and scatters of slag and charcoal.

events.title: Au Sable Point Lightstation
events.description:
The lightstation was completed in 1874 and automated in 1958. The original site features include a light-tower connected to a two-story keeper's house, and oil house, and a privy. By 1909, another two-story dwelling, fog signal building, boat house, and metal storage building were added.

Surface survey and excavations at the site located two possible root cellars and trash dumps associated with the complex. Artifacts found include glass, brick, ceramics, and a glass marble.

Image from www.nps.gov.

events.title: Moccasin Bluff
events.description:
This multicomponent site has been occupied for many thousands of years. The site includes camps, earthworks, and one of the most significant Upper Mississippian sites in Michigan. The site was first excavated in 1948, but people have known about it since before then. These early excavations revealed a very early occupation, approximately 6300 B.C., as well as small later occupations. The most substantial occupation at the site, however, starts about A.D. 1060 and lasts to 1640, based on radiocarbon dates. A vareity of features have been identified, including smudge pits (for tanning hides), storage pits, hearths, and fire pits for baking. This site is signficant because it provided information on the transition from the Late Archaic period through the Late Woodland period.

Image courtesy of the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office, of excavations conducted in 1948.

events.title: Fort St. Joseph
events.description:
Initially the site of a French mission, a fort and trading post grew up in the location during the early part of the eighteenth century. In 1761, the Briitsh took ove the fort. The fort was looted in a raid by the Spanish in 1781, who held it for a day. Archaeological work at the site has been ongoing since 1998, through field schools conducted by Western Michigan University.

Image from www.wmich.edu.

events.title: Assinins
events.description:
This is the site of a mission, orphanage, and Native American settlement founded by Frederic Baraga. Originally, the complex covered 497 acres and included over 15 log houses.

Assinins is one of Father Frederic Baraga's earliest Upper Peninsula Catholic missions, and includes some of the oldest structures in the region. The mission was founded in 1843, and destroyed in 1873. Father Baraga wrote his best known work here, a book on Chippewa grammar and a Chippewa dictionary. The Old St. Joseph Orphanage and school were built on the site in 1860. A larger orphanage was built in 1929. The buildings were used for the Capuchin Fathers as a friary in the 1950s and 1960s. The grounds now house the Keweenaw Bay Indian Tribal Center.

Image from www.baragacountyhistoricalmuseum.com.

events.title: Sand Point
events.description:
This site contains a large village and several earthworks. Radiocarbon dates from the site include A.D. 1055, A.D. 1220, and A.D. 330. Western Michigan University conducted excavations at the site in the 1970s and located a large variety of copper tools, including a crescent, necklace, flat spiral bead, tinkling cone, and 15 rolled beads. Copper tools included awls, barbs, twist drill, hook, harpoon fragment, and projectile points. Many ceramic vessels have also been found on the site, both grit-tempered and shell-tempered.

This site is significant for the variety of artifacts, the intact features, variety of features and artifactual evidence for how people were living during this time.

Image courtesy of Susan Kooiman.

events.title: Fletcher
events.description:
The site has been continuously occupied since the Late Archaic period, however the most well known component is from the late eighteenth century, when a cemetery was found. The Late Archaic/Early Woodland component of the site is known from a buried paleosol that contained multiple pit and hearth features. Artifacts found here included Satchell points, bifaces, cores, drills, scrapers, and other chipped stone tools. This period of occupation has been interpreted as a seasonal camp.

Image from http://www.archaeowiki.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Genesee.jpg/350px-Genesee.jpg

events.title: Platte River
events.description:
The site consists of a hearth, scatter of artifacts and much later homestead foundations. A radiocarbon date came out to AD 260 +/- 80. Floral and faunal remains (grape, cranberry, nannyberry, fish, and turtle) indicate that the site was occupied during warm weather. A smaller Late Woodland camp was also located.

Despite some disturbance at the site, it was in relatively good condition with intact features present. The presence of crushed ceramic vessels here is uncommon in this area of Michigan. For these reasons, and the fact that the artifacts can be used as a sample to contrast with other regional artifact assemblages, it was listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

Image from Wikipedia Commons, from Jeffrey J. Richner, 1991, Archeological Excavations at the Platte River Campground Site (20BZ16), Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore .

events.title: Naomikong Point
events.description:
The site is largely a Middle Woodland period fishing camp. Ceramics are plentiful, as well as fishing gear and copper items. A smaller Late Woodland component is also present. Features present include post molds, refuse pits, and middens.

This site is significant for the variety of features, artifacts, and evidence for how people were living during this time period.

Image courtesy of Susan Kooiman.

events.title: Old Fort Brady
events.description:
Old Fort Brady was constructed in 1822 near the site of the previous French Fort Repentigny. The fort was a military outpost to protect the straits. Artifacts have been recovered from the fort, from a series of excavations by both Michigan State University and Lake Superior State University.

Image from www.lssu.edu.

events.title: Fort Drummond
events.description:
The fort was established by the British garrison in 1815, after the evacuation of Fort Mackinac at the end fo the War of 1812. The military post and adjacent settlement functioned as the center of British trade until 1828 when Drummond Island became part of the United States.
Archaeologists have identified seventy-four fort and village features, including stone foundaitnos, structural depressions, standing stone chimneys, wharves, wells, trash pits, privies ,and a semi-subterranean hut. Excavations in the officers' quarters, store, mess, and a residence located white clay pipes, ceramics, beads, shot and gun parts, military buttons and insignia, bottles, and trade goods.

Image from Wikipedia Commons.

events.title: Leavitt
events.description:
The Leavitt site consists of a Paleo-Indian occupation. A single feature has been identified by archaeologists, a shallow pit filled with lithic debitage. Other artifacts include side and end scrapers, cores, and a fluted point base. Several bifaces from the Early Archaic period were also recovered.

This site is significant in that very few sites from this time period have been found and excavated. This site provides crucial information on how people lived during this early time period. While it is not on the National Register of Historic Places, it provides a significant piece of information on Michigan's past and for that reason, was included here.

Image from Shott (1993), page 86.

events.title: Garden Island Cemetery
events.description: Odawa cemetery site, listed on the National Register in 1978.

events.title: New Fort Brady
events.description: This fort was constructed to replace Old Fort Brady. It was located on a rise of ground, overlooking the city. Many of the fort's original buildings still stand, and have been incorporated into Lake Superior State University's campus.

events.title: Schoolcraft House
events.description: This was once the home of Henry Schoolcraft (Indian agent and author). Archaeological work located many atifacts related to this early occupation, as well as evidence for prehistoric occupation.

events.title: Johnston House
events.description: This was John Johnston's house. He married a Chippewa woman and became a central figure in the region.

events.title: Campbell Farm
events.description: Originally purchased by Robert Campbell in 1790, a mill complex was stablished at the site.  The Campbells also had a farm complex here.  The farm was sold to Michael Dousman in 1819, and mill operations ceased in 1839.

events.title: Old Mackinac Point Light Station
events.description:
In 1889, Congress appropriated funds for the construction of a steam-powered fog signal here, which went into operation in 1890. A light tower and keeper's dwelling were finished in 1892. The light was in operation until 1958. Archaeological work on the interior of the barn and a privy has been done at the site.

Image from Wikipedia Commons.

events.title: Pi-wan-go-ning Quarry
events.description:
This site includes the main outcrop of Norwood chert. It has been utilized by people since the Archaic period, and there is evidence on site of quarrying and stone tool manufacture.

This site is significant for several reasons. It was a significant source of raw material for people for a long time. It has also revealed evidence about these people through the variety of point styles found at the site.

Image is provided courtesy of the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office.

events.title: Fritz Trail & Whiskey Creek
events.description:
These sites are the location of several outcroppings of Norwood chert. Some limestone quarrying has been done here as well. Evidence of stone tool manufacture is also evident, including debitage, cores, and core fragments. Ground stone tools, necessary for producing chipped stone artifacts, have also been found here. This was an early site of raw material collection.

Image from the Office of the State Archaeologist, University of Iowa.

events.title: Mt. McSauba
events.description: This seasonal Late Woodland camp has had a series of excavations. An OSL date from the site came to 740 +/-70. Michigan State University first discovered the site in 1969, then excavated it in 1972. The site is located on an eroding beach and dune area, and consists of many buried living surfaces, many with cultural material (artifacts) still in their original location. Despite being located on the Lake Michigan shoreline, no fish remains were recovered.

events.title: Inwood Creek I & II
events.description:
Inwood Creek I & II are Late Archaic sites with distinct soil layers and have been tested. They are located on what was probably a dune near the beach during the Late Archaic period. Artifacts from these deposits include finely-flaked Archaic points and chert debitage.

Image courtesy of the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office.

events.title: O'Neill
events.description:
The site seems to have been used for spring fishing and visiting the nearby quarry. The O'Neill portion of the site is later, with a very distincitve type of ceramics. Two nearly complete vessels and the post-mold outline of an oval house were both found here. A large hearth near the dwelling yielded a radiocarbon date of 1455 +/-100.

Image courtesy of the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office.

events.title: Charlevoix City Park
events.description: Michigan State University excavated at this site in 1969.  Surface collections were done of the site in 1968, 1969 and 1976. The ceramics from the collection date the site to approximately A.D. 1350.

events.title: Greensky Hill Mission
events.description:
A small mission was built here in 1839 by Peter Greensky. A log building was constructed in 1861. The church has been preserved with all of the original woodwork and can only seat about 50 people.

Image courtesy of By rossograph - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=40682104

events.title: Feodar Protar House
events.description: Feodar Protar was a healer from Russia on Beaver Island.

events.title: Summer Island
events.description: This warm season camp contained at least four oval houses approximately 8 meters long and 5 meters wide.  Hearths, drying racks, storage pits, and refuse areas were also present.  Archaeologists have found a variety of tools for fishing and netmaking, as well as a variety of copper tools.  Radiocarbon dates place occupation at the site from the Early Woodland through the Late Woodland (320 BC to AD 1500), with another occupation around 1620 with evidence for European goods. This site is significant in that the successive occupations here show different adaptations to the same environment.

events.title: Winter
events.description:
This site was occupied during warm weather during the Middle Woodland period. A clay lined pit was found by archaeologists, as well as flakes of exotic cherts (Knife River and obsidian), hammerstones, anvils, end scrapers, bipolar cores, pigments, copper tools, and ceramics. Faunal remains suggest that people living here ate fall-spawning fish. This site is significant in that it represents early experimentation with coastal living in the late fall and winter.

Image courtesy of William Lovis.

events.title: Fayette
events.description:
This iron smelting complex and town is now a state park, with many of the original structures still standing. Industrial buildings include the charcoal and limestone kilns and the smelters, while residential buildings include laborers' cabins, doctor's house, supervisor's house, boarding house, school, hotel, and company store. Excavations at the site have provided evidence for differences in class and health across the site, as well as revealing a prehistoric component.

Image from www.michigan.gov.

events.title: Spider Cave
events.description:
This series of wave cut niches contain the only known pictographs in the state of Michigan, or painted images. Most of the information on the site comes from the 1960s, when the site was owned privately. The site was purchased by the State of Michigan, and in 1963 limited excavations were conducted. The cave was found to contain over 90 projectile points of stone and antler, along with the rock paintings of colors ranging from red through blue.

Image copyright Jessica Yann.

events.title: Graved Rock
events.description: Graved Rock is a series of petroglyph of unknown age. They are located on the wall of a gorge.

events.title: River Park
events.description: This small Woodland camp contains a basalt cobble with faint decorative markings that may depict a stylized animal. A single potsherd was also found at the site in one of the severla basin-shaped features.

events.title: Sliding Stump
events.description: This Woodland camp contains several hearth features and a vareity of lithic and ceramic artifacts.

events.title: Up Stream Put-In Site
events.description: This Woodland camp contains several intact features including hearths with the possibility of other deeply buried features. Artifacts included flakes, a triangular projectile point, charcoal, and fire-cracked rock.

events.title: Bike Trail
events.description: This small Woodland camp contains several features and a variety of lithic artifacts. A single tiny potsherd was found.  This site is significant for its location in the Western Upper Peninsula.

events.title: Wycamp Creek
events.description: This multi-component site has a Middle Woodland component, Late Woodland component, and Seventeenth century component. The site is unusual in that there is a wide range in the types of artifacts present, both in the pottery and the stone tools. One idea for why this occurs is that this region served as a cultural connection between several different areas of the Great Lakes.  There is also considerable evidence at the site for stone tool manufacture, showing a wide range of techniques, and a great degree of skill.

events.title: Ponshewaing Point
events.description: This Middle Woodland/Late Woodland camp contains a variety of projectile points, drills, wedges, bifaces, scrapers, and other lithics.

events.title: Fort Michilimackinac
events.description:
The fort was initially established by the French around 1715 by the French to protect and facilitate trade with the various Native groups in the region. The French surrendered the fort to the British in 1760. The British moved the fort to Mackinac Island in 1780. The fort played a significant role in the history of the region during the 17th and 18th centuries.

Image from Wikipedia Commons.

events.title: Brown
events.description: Excavations by Alma College revealed a small Late Woodland site, containing triangular points and fabric-impressed ceramics. Fragments from at least seven undecorated elbow pipes were also found, along with bifaces and scrapers. Features at the site contained charcoal, some of which was used to obtain radiocarbon dates.

events.title: Pine River Park
events.description:
This site is sometimes also referred to as Conservation Park. Excavations at this site have located several features, including two hearths. These provided radiocarbon dates for this site of 2515 +/- 145 years before present and 2750+/- 150 years before present. This site marks the transition to new ways of life as agriculture was introduced into Michigan. Both organic remains and features at the site have the potential to offer more information on this time period.

Image courtesy of the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office.

events.title: Skegemog Point
events.description: This large site includes several distinct Late Woodland occupations.  Over 50 features were documented by Michigan State University during excavations, including 26 hearths.  The most interesting of the features is the many postmolds, outlining cirular structures (see image here). Artifacts include ceramics, triangular points, end scrapers, bifaces, and debitage. The ceramic assemblage is large and quite varied, providing evidence for some sort of interaction between various groups.

events.title: Holiday Park
events.description: Excavations here located 15 undisturbed features (hearths and pits), along with a large pottery assemblage.  The site had not been plowed at all, so none of the deposits were disturbed. Radiocarbon dates were done from the pottery, providing a date much later than expected (1230-1470).  This site is unique in that it shows the type of information lost due to plowing. It also contains a large and varied ceramic assemblage, which can be used to study how people interacted in this region during this time.

events.title: Quincy Mining Company
events.description:
Covering approximately 80 acres, the Quincy Mine complex includes many of the original buildings, including the water tower, engine house, and several boilerhouses. Archaeological work at the site has located a variety of artifacts indicative of life at the mine, including clay marbles, clay pipe stems, and a pocket knife.

Image from www.mtu.edu.

events.title: Pointe Aux Barques Lighthouse
events.description:
This is one of the ten oldest lighthouses in Michigan. The tower assisted navigation into Saginaw Bay. Archaeological features include the remains of a wooden dock, as well as artifacts from the lighthouse keeper's residence.

Image from http://www.pointeauxbarqueslighthouse.org.

events.title: Camp Gibbs
events.description: Camb Gibbs is a former Civilian Conservation Corps Camp.  Many of the original buildings are still standing. Contributing elements include the Mess Hall, Shower House, Pumphouse, four Barracks, Recreation Hall site, Headquarters/laundry, Barracks site, Quarters, Infirmary, Pole Shed, New Kitchen, Hiawatha Club, Carpenter's Shop, Playhouse, foundation remains, trash dock, and dump.  A dump is nearby where supplies and equipment were buried when the camp was abandoned in 1941.

events.title: McCargoe Cove
events.description: The town of Cove served the Minong Mine.  It is represented by foundations, surface scatter, and underwater remains around the dock.

events.title: Five Channels Dam Complex
events.description: This complex includes the structures erected to aid in the construction of the Five Channels Dam.  The buildings were in use into the 1960s. Multiple artifacts have been located that help illuminate life during this time in the worker camps.

events.title: Fort Wilkins
events.description:
Fort Wilkins was constructed to police and protect the copper miners and prospectors in the Keweenaw. The army abandoned the fort in 1870. Archaeological excavations have been undertaken at the site since 1976. These artifacts have helped illuminate life at the fort during its operation, as well as aid in public interpretation of the site. A number of the original structures have also been restored.

Image from www.michigan.org.

events.title: Norton Mounds
events.description:
The Norton Mound Group is a National Historic Landmark, and is one of the best preserved Hopewellian burial centers in the country. Once a part of an extensive system of over 30 mounds, 11 still retain their basic form. The University of Michigan undertook excavations in the 1960s. The information gathered demonstrated these people had a massive trade network, with artifacts like pearls, copper beads, and marine shells.

Image from Wikipedia Commons, Robert Smith (February 1966), “Excavating the Hopewell Burial Mounds at Grand Rapids”, in Research News[1], volume 16.

events.title: Walker Tavern
events.description:
Walker Tavern was built in 1843 where it served as a stop for the stagecoach route from Chicago to Detroit. After it closed in 1865, it was privately run as a tourist attraction. The site was acquired by DNR in the 1960s. Archaeological work at the site has illuminated the lifestyle of the Walkers as well as the Hewitt family.

Image from Wikipedia Commons.

events.title: Younge
events.description: This site includes the remains of longhouses with pits and hearths.  Pottery, projectile points, and elbow pipes were all recovered.  A large cemetery was also found at the site.  This is the type site for the Younge Phase and Younge Tradition.

events.title: Glen Haven Sawmill
events.description: The Glen Haven sawmill was constructed along with a horse-drawn tramway as part of the village of Glen Haven.  Several features remain including stone features, piers, collapsed brick structures, and metal causeways.

events.title: Aetna Earthworks
events.description:
These circular earthworks consist of a bank and ditch. Numerous ceramic vessels have been recovered from around the enclosures.

Image from Wikipedia commons, Aetna Earthworks, Missaukee County MI c1923. Prof. Hinsdale standing on tree crossing the moat portion of the earthwork, Prof Ruthven standing below.

events.title: Boven Earthworks
events.description: This circular enclosure with a ditch also contains evidence for a stockade around the site.  There is minimal evidence for occupation around the enclosure though there is some charcoal and pottery. Post molds have been identified, representing the palisade, that surrounded the outer perimeter of the mound.  There are not many known surviving earthworks site in Michigan, making this site unique.

events.title: Holcombe
events.description:
This single component site contained evidence for a Paleo-Indian camp. It was discovered in 1960, and excavations were conducted in 1961. A wide range of artifacts have been found at the site. Wood found at the site has been radiocarbon dated to 11,200 +/- 300 years and 10,860 +/- 350 years ago, placing the site at just prior to 11,000 years ago. This site has provided the only direct evidence of diet during this time period for Michigan, a single caribou bone. This is also some of the earliest evidence for diet in Michigan.

Image from http://www.projectilepoints.net/Points/Holcombe.html

events.title: Oxbow Archaeological District
events.description: This district contains many archaeological sites found in a small area, which indicates a large population in this location prehistorically. Sites include camps, earthworks, and surface scatters of artifacts. While individual sites may not provide a significant amount of information on the past, taken together they demonstrate...

events.title: Riverside
events.description: This is a large multicomponent village and cemetery complex. Features include middens, burials, and postmolds. Artifacts from the site include bifaces, obsidian, bone tools, and a variety of copper atifacts. Perhaps the most interesting artifact from the site is a piece of copper, that through radiographic and metallurgic analysis, has been found to be of cast copper.

events.title: Juntunen
events.description: This Woodland camp site includes hearth features, refuse pits, a long house, animal burials, and human burials. Burials include two ossuaries.  This site was a significant center of activity for people during this time period.

events.title: Gros Cap Archaeological District
events.description: This village and associated cemetery contain many discrete features dating to the 17th and 18th centuries. There is evidence for cache pits at the site as well.  The site provides good evidence for how life changed with the influx of Europeans during the late 17th century.

events.title: Fort Mackinac
events.description:
Fort Mackinac was constructed when the British decided to move their base of operations from the straits to Mackinac Island. Fort Michilimackinac was disassembled and reassembled at the new location. The fort was turned over to the United States in 1796, but retaken by the British in 1812. It was reoccupied by the US in 1815, where it operated as a military post until 1895. Excavations at the fort have revealed information about daily life, as well as infomation on early trash disposal and drainage systems at the fort.

Image from Wikipedia Commons.

events.title: Lasanen
events.description: This late 17th century ossuary was disturbed by construction, prompting salvage excavations.  These excavations have revealed much about continuity of burial practices in the straits, as well as life during this time period.

events.title: Scott Point
events.description: This camp/village site includes numerous hearth and storage pits, a large variety of ceramics, bone tools, and copper implements.  Three radiocarbon dates have been done on the site, 860 +/-40, 870+/-40, and 1240+/-40.

events.title: Gyftakis
events.description: Excavations at this camp have revealed a variety of pottery, some with food residue. Numerous ceramic vessels have been recovered here.

events.title: Marquette Street Archaeological District
events.description:
The Marquette Street Archaeological District includes the village of Te Oskonchiae and the Marquette Mission site. The village includes the archaeological remains of long houses and a palisade for a 17th/18th century Native American village. The mission is generally associated to Father Marquette and French missionaries. Numerous artifacts have been found that demonstrate Native American groups were incorporating European trade goods into their culture.

Image from http://www.stignace.com/backend/uploads/cms/images/Museum-of-Ojibay-Culture-St-Ignace.jpg.

events.title: Carp River Forge
events.description:
The Jackson Mining Company began construction of a forge complex in 1846, soon after the discovery of iron in the Upper Peninsula. It first produced in 1848, but was never financially successful and was abandoned in 1855. The complex consists of a dam and waterwheel, forge, two cold-blast bloomeries, four hot blast furnaces, sawmill, store, and houses.

Image from Wikipedia commons.

events.title: North Maumee Bay Archaeological District
events.description: This district includes numerous archaeological sites representative of the Late Woodland people residing along Lake Huron.  Villages, camps, and other features demonstrate a complex series of habitations. Numerous radiocarbon dates have been obtained for these sites.  The people living here fished, gathered, and left behind a variety of ceramic vessels.

events.title: River Raisin Battlefield
events.description:
The Battle of the River Raisin was fought in January of 1813. British and Native American allies attached the settlement of Frenchtown, along with their Kentucky militia allies. This is the best known battle ever fought on Michigan soil.

Image from www.nps.gov.

events.title: Navarre-Anderson Trading Post
events.description:
The original cabin was moved in 1894, but had served as a trading post for many years. Seed beads from trade were found when the structure was moved, and lead from the bullet holes form the War of 1812. Excavations at the site have revealed a variety of ceramics.

Image from Wikipedia commons.

events.title: Spring Creek
events.description: This large camp contains hearths, refuse pits, and postmolds from circular lodges. Many ceramics and stone tools have been found, and faunal remains suggest repeated winter occupations by small groups of people.

events.title: Croton Dam Mound Group
events.description:
This Early Woodland mound group provides some of the earliest evidence for mounds in Michigan. Features found during excavations near the mounds include a hearth containing over 100 stemmed points and bifaces. Another mound contained animal bones, a rolled copper bead, and a red ochre deposit.

These mounds are significant because they are some of the earliest mounds known in the state.

events.title: Toft Lake Village
events.description: This Middle Woodland village is unique in that it provides evidence on a single component of life.

events.title: Dumaw Creek
events.description:
This village and cemetery site is unique in that it dates to the cusp of contact with Europeans, dating to the mid-seventeenth century. Many unique copper items have been found at the site, including copper hair pipes and beads.

Image from Quimby (1966):38.

events.title: Green Quarry
events.description:
This quarry contains over 100 quarry pits and a surface scatter covering over 40 acres. This quarry is a source of Lambrix chert. This chert is distinctive from either Bayport or Norwood and is primarily a brown-gray color. It is a high quality chert, that is easy to use to create stone tools. The chert occurs as glacial cobbles; there are no apparent outcrops here. This site is distinct in that it is the only known quarry for this chert type. Additionally, people have been using the site continuously since the Paleo-Indian period.

Image courtesy of the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office.

events.title: Van Hoosen Farm
events.description:
This nineteenth century farm complex started as a double log cabin in 1823. A Greek Revival style frame house was constructed in 1840. Archaeology on the site has revealed numerous kinds of artifacts, which have aided in the public interpretation of the site.

Image from http://www.rochesterhills.org.

events.title: Spoonville
events.description: This extensive, multicomponent site represents one of the most intact Hopewell site complexes in Michigan.  The Middle to early Late Woodland mound and habitation site has had many excavations.

events.title: Battle Point
events.description: A 19th century Ottawa cemetery that was identified from erosion.  Efforts have been made to stabilize the site and identify its boundaries so that it can be protected.  This site has yielded one of the largest assemblages for this time period, and provides significant information about cultural change among Native American groups.

events.title: Green Point
events.description:
Excavations at Green Point have been done by the University of Michigan and Michigan State University. Buried layers of human activity have been found. However, the site is most significant for providing evidence for early domesticate use (squash). Three seeds found here may date to the Terminal Archaic/Early Woodland period.

Image is a stock image of squash seeds.

events.title: Schultz
events.description: This is the type site for Early and Middle Woodland sites in the Saginaw region. It contains distinct strata from different time periods. The site contains evidence for squash. It is significant in that it is the site against which all other sites from this time/region are compared to.

events.title: Schmidt
events.description:
Excavations at this Middle Archaic site revealed several features, including an undisturbed midden feature. Radiocarbon dates were done from several of the features, providing dates between 6900 and 5200 years before present. Artifacts include a variety of stone tools, a bone awl, animal bone, and nuts and seeds. Deer and bird bones found at the site suggest a fall occupation, though muskrat and fish remains suggest people also lived here in the spring and summer. Given this evidence, people probably used this location all year round. The site is considered significant as one of the few Archaic period sites from this time period.

Image from Harrison (1966), page 59.

events.title: Mahoney
events.description:
This stratified site contains multiple features (fourteen), including hearths, storage and refuse pits, and a living surface. The pottery at the site reveals that while people were living here during the Late Woodland period, they maintained a variety of ceramic styles for other times and places. The site is significant in that it contains the remains of numerous small seasonal campsites that have been well preserved well below the plow zone.

THis site is significant in that it contains numerous small campsites from the Woodland period. Most of the site is intact, and there are probably undisturbed deposits below the plow zone. Further excavation could reveal more about settlement patterns (how sites relate to one another), seasonal data, adaptations to climate change, and how people interacted.

events.title: Bugai
events.description: Salvage excavations were conducted here, revealing a Wayne Mortuary Tradition site. This site is the most important Wayne Mortuary Tradition site in the Saginaw Valley.

events.title: Fort Gratiot
events.description:
Fort Gratiot was constructed in 1814, during the War of 1812, to control Great Lakes shipping. It was abandoned in 1821 and then a second fort built on the ruins in 1828. This fort was used until 1879. Archaeological work has been done at the site, revealing buried features from both building episodes of the fort.

Image from www.midwestconnection.org/Lighthouses/lk_huronLT/images/fortgratiotcg1.jpg.

events.title: US Land Office
events.description: This former United States Land Office Building housed the US land office, which was responsible for the slae of 328,000 acres of governemnt lands.  The privy at the site was excavated by bottle hunters; no information is known about how this related to the occupation of the structure.

events.title: Sanilac Petroglyphs
events.description:
This sandstone outcrop is covered in carved petroglyphs in a variety of images. Archaeological work around the rock has located flakes, pottery, and fire-cracked rock.

Image from www.michigan.gov.

events.title: Seul Choix
events.description: This site has been excavated, and OSL dates have been done on the ceramics.

events.title: Detroit Dry Dock Co. complex
events.description:
The Detroit Dry Dock Company complex once included two dry docks, a shipyard, associated support structures, sawmill, loft and office. THe first dry dock was built to service schooners, while the second to service larger steam vessels. Dock #1 may be the only intact 19th century dry dock in the Great Lakes region.

Image from Wikipedia Commons.

events.title: Hull's Trace
events.description:
This is a portion of the corduroy road that was once part of the military and early territorial road running from Maumee, Ohio to Detroit. Construction is believed to have been started in the summer of 1812 as part of the strengthening of defenses against the British. Major improvements to the road were done in 1817 and 1818.

The road was covered by rising waters, but exposed by low water levels in 1930 and 2000. In 2012, 633 visible logs were identified spanning 380 meters, some with rings clearly visible.

Image from Wikipedia Commons.

events.title: Mount Pleasant Indian Industrial Boarding School
events.description:
This boarding school was built to educate Native American children, many of who were taken forcibly from their homes. Several buildings are extant, and archaeological work around them has helped provide more information on the life of the students.

Image from www.sagchip.org.
